snippet: Doctors with a financial interest in a laboratory are more likely to send prostate samples, according to a new study, but the rate of cancer detection is no higher.
abstract: Dr Jean M Mitchell study in journal Health Affairs finds that urologists with a financial interest in a laboratory send more prostate biopsies for analysis and have a lower rate of cancer detection than those who use independent labs.
lead_paragraph: Doctors with a financial interest in a laboratory are more likely to send prostate samples, according to a new study, but the rate of cancer detection is no higher.

headline.seo: Urologist’s Stake in Laboratory Affects Number of Prostate Biopsies
headline.main: Patterns: Doctor’s Stake in Lab Affects Biopsy Rate
headline.print_headline: Patterns: Doctor’s Stake in Lab Affects Biopsy Rate
